statement:
For every natural number $n$, let ${\left(n\underline{!}\right)_p}$
denote the product of numbers $1
\le m \le n$ with $gcd(m,p) =1$.

For prime $p$ and $s \in \mathbb{N}$
$${\left(p^s\underline{!}\right)_p} \equiv \left(
\begin{array}{ll}
1 & \mbox{for } p=2, s \ge 3 \\
-1 & \mbox{otherwise}
\end{array}\right. \pmod{p^s}.$$

**Proof:** We pair up all factors of the product
${\left(p^s\underline{!}\right)_p}$ into those numbers $m$ where
$m \not\equiv m^{-1} \pmod{p^s}$ and those where this is not the case.
So ${\left(p^s\underline{!}\right)_p}$ is congruent (modulo $p^s$) to
the product of those numbers $m$ where
$m \equiv m{-1} \pmod{p^s} \leftrightarrow m^2 \equiv 1
\pmod{p^s}$.

Let $p$ be an odd prime and $s \in \mathbb{N}$. Since $2 \not\vert p^s$,
$p^s
\vert (m^2 -1)$ implies $p^s \vert (m +1)$ either or $p^s \vert (m-1)$.
This leads to $${\left(p^s\underline{!}\right)_p} \equiv -1 \pmod{p^s}$$
for odd prime $p$ and any $s \in \mathbb{N}$.

Now let $p=2$ and $s \ge 2$. Then
$$\left(1 +t.2^{s-1}\right)^2 \equiv 1 \pmod{2^s}, t =\stackrel{-}{+}1.$$
Since
$$\left(2^{s -1} +1\right)\left(2^{s-1} -1\right) \equiv -1 \pmod{2^s},$$
we have
$${\left(p^s\underline{!}\right)_p} \equiv (-1).(-1) =1 \pmod{p^s}$$ For
$p=2, s \ge 3$, but $-1$ for $s=1,2. \square$
